China b State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taoyuan South Road 27, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taoyuan South Road 27 Taiyuan 030001 PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taoyuan South Road 27, Taiyuan 030001, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Selective oxidation of glycerol to dihydroxyacetone (DHA) is a promising pathway for glycerol utilization. In order to fabricate a highly stable supported Au catalyst for the reaction, a series of CuO-ZnO mixed oxides derived from different minerals were synthesized. Then, the Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation. High yield of DHA (70%) and conversion of glycerol (76%) were obtained over the rosasite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst. While over the aurichalcite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst, the yield of DHA was only 20%. By means of XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS, CO2-TPD characterization, it was found that the higher yield of DHA was attributed to the stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO, higher dispersion of Au species, higher content of Au0 and proper amount of surface basic sites. The rosasite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst also showed good stability and no obvious decrease in reactivity and DHA selectivity could be seen after five recycles. The stable structure of the support not only enhanced the interaction between CuO-ZnO that stabilized the support itself, but also improved the interaction between Au and the support, further stabilizing the particle size and chemical valence of Au. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol oxidation Dihydroxyacetone Au-based catalyst Good stability CuO-ZnO support Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a by-product of the manufacture of the biodiesel, glycerol is generated in large amounts and has thus received intensive attention due to the high added value of its oxygenated derivatives [1–7], such as glyceric acid (GLA), hydroxypurivic acid (HA), dihydroxyactone (DHA) and tartronic acid (TA) [8–10]. Among these derivatives, DHA is the most economically important product due to the wide applications in cosmetics and organic synthesis [11]. In the recent years, heterogeneous Au catalysts have found applications in alcohol oxidation [12–15], which was more stable and selective than Pt and Pd-based catalyst [16]. Previous studies on selective oxidation of glycerol over Au-based catalysts was in the presence of alkaline media [17–20], which would alter the intrinsic reaction mechanism and made it difficult to offer a high selectivity to DHA [21,22]. To circumvent the problem, there had been many studies on supported gold catalysts in base-free conditions. Xu et al. [23] prepared a series of Au/metal oxide (MOx) catalysts and achieved a high DHA yield of 80% at 50 °C over Au/CuO catalyst. Li et al. [24,25] synthesized Au/ZnO catalyst with the DHA yield of 51.3% at 80 °C. It was found that the Au/ZnO interface was the specific active site for the reaction. In our previous studies [26,27], the Au/CuO-ZrO2 catalysts were prepared which exhibited excellent catalytic performance (yield of 80% at 60 °C). Combined with characterization results, it was found that the basicity of the catalyst would affect the conversion of glycerol. The interaction between Au and the Cu-Zr mixed oxides also influenced the dispersion and the chemical valence state of Au which then further affected the glycerol conversion. These studies suggested that the nature of the support had great effects on the activity of the catalysts [28]. However, efforts were still needed to explore the relationship between the intrinsic properties of the support and the catalytic performance in order to achieve more efficient conversion of glycerol to DHA. In addition, the stability of the supported Au catalyst was also significant with the adsorption of by-products and the aggregation of Au particles being the main reasons for the decreased activity [24,26]. Previous researches also showed that the bimetallic composite oxide-supported Au catalysts (Au/MMO) had better stability than monometallic oxide supported Au catalysts (Au/MO) [10,24,26]. The synergies of multiple supports might promote the stability of the catalyst. The abundant interface between the support and the metal might enhance both activity and selectivity simultaneously. CuO-ZnO mixed oxide had been used as a support for the oxidation of glycerol [29]. Improving stability was still an urgent problem. In this work, we aimed to synthesize DHA over Au-based catalyst with high stability in base-free conditions, which was a challenging but scientifically and industrially valuable work. Herein, a series of mineral-derived CuO-ZnO mixed oxides with different textures and surface properties were prepared as supports. Then, the Au was loaded by deposition-precipitation. The as-prepared catalysts could efficiently catalyze the selective conversion of glycerol to DHA with high stability. The highest yield of DHA was obtained over the rosasite-derived CuO-ZnO mixed oxide supported catalyst. Combined with XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS and CO2-TPD characterization, the influence of the precursor structure on the catalyst structure and performance was also discussed. As far as we know, the application of Au catalysts supported on different mineral-derived CuO-ZnO mixed oxides for selective oxidation of glycerol was firstly reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the CuO-ZnO supports were prepared by co-precipitation method [30]. Typically, 0.125 mol of Cu(NO3)2 (Tianjin Beichen Fangzheng Co., Ltd) and Zn(NO3)2 (J&K Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) with preset Cu/Zn molar ratios were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water (Solution A). 0.125 mol of Na2CO3 (Sinopharm Chemical Co., Ltd) was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water (Solution B). The two solutions were then added dropwise into a vessel at 70 °C under vigorous stirring. After precipitation, the as-formed suspensions were aged for 1 h at 70 °C and then filtered. Thus, the filter cakes were washed with deionized water and dried overnight at 100 °C, followed by calcination in static air at 400 °C for 4 h. The as-synthesized samples were denoted as CuxZn1−x (x = 1, 0.9, 0.7, 0.5). Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts with 2.0 wt% Au loading were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. The same procedure was used in our previous work [26,27]. NaAuCl4·3 H2O (Shanxi Kaida Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd.) was used as the Au precursor. Briefly, 2 mL of 10 mgAu/mL solution of NaAuCl4 was added to 50 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 1 g of CuO-ZnO support and 2.44 g of urea (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.). The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 6 h, followed by aging at room temperature overnight. After that, the suspensions were filtered and washed by deionized water until no Cl- was detected. The as-obtained solid was dried at 110 °C and calcined under flowing air at 200 °C for 5 h. For comparison, the Au/CuO catalyst was prepared by the same method. 2.2 Evaluation of glycerol oxidation The glycerol oxidation reactions were carried out in a 70 mL reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer with the stirring speed of 700 rpm. Typically, 20 mL of glycerol solution (0.1 M) and a certain amount of catalysts were charged into the reactor. The glycerol/Au molar ratio was 500 to 25. The reactor was pressurized at 0.2 MPa of pure O2 after purging with O2 for 10 times which was then heated to the specified temperature (50, 60, 70 and 80, 90 °C), the stirrer was turned on and the reaction started. After reaction for a certain time (1–12 h), the reactor was cooled immediately in cold water. The solid catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The products were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography equipped with Aminex HPX-87 H column and refractive index and UV detectors. The wavelength of the UV detector was 210 nm. The analysis conditions were the same as our previous work [26,27]. The column oven temperature was 60 °C, and the mobile phase was 0.005 mol/L H2SO4 solution. The equations for calculating the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity of the products were as follows: C o n v . % = ( i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l − m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l a f t e r r e a c t i o n ) i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l × 100 % S e l . % = i 3 × m o l e s o f a s p e c i f i c p r o d u c t i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l − m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l a f t e r r e a c t i o n × 100 % In which i represented the number of C atoms in the specific product molecule. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Au metal loading as well as the Cu and Zn content of the catalysts were determined by ICP analysis. N2 physisorption was conducted in a Micrometrics 3020 Physical Adsorber at −196°C. Specific surface areas were obtained by using the method of Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). The pore sizes were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8-Focus diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation (40 V, 40 mA, l¼1.54056 A) in a θ-θ mode from 10 to 80 degrees. The surface basicity of the catalysts was determined by CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) on GC-950 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector (see details in [27]). The reduction properties of the catalysts were determined by H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on GC-950 gas chromatograph. Specifically, 0.05 g (40–60 mesh) of catalyst was loaded in the middle of the quartz tube. Then, the catalyst was purged with argon at 200 °C for 1 h to remove the impurities adsorbed on the surface. After cooling to room temperature, the 5% H2-Ar mixture was introduced. After the baseline was stable, the sample was heated from room temperature to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The H2 signal during the reduction was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed on JMF2100 to obtain the Au particle size distributions. The mean diameter of particles was calculated by measuring at least 200 particles in the micrographs. The dispersion of Au was calculated as the reciprocal of the mean diameter of Au particle measured by TEM. The chemical composition and the chemical state of the Au on the catalyst surface was explored by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a dual Mg/Al X-ray source. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Cu-Zn composite oxide precursors The molecular formula of malachite is [Cu2(CO3)(OH)2]. Due to the Jahn-Teller effect of the Cu2+ ions, there are two varying degrees of twisted CuO6 octahedral structures i.e. coordinated with O atoms on six CO3 2- and/or OH- ions. Rosasite ([(Cu,Zn)2(CO3)(OH)2]) is a binary mineral salt transformed from malachite formed by Zn2+ ions entering the malachite crystals[31,32]. The average Jahn-Teller distortions of the MO6 octahedra in the malachite crystal structure are lowered as Cu2+ ions are gradually substituted by Zn2+. According to the literature, rosasite phase can be synthesized only when the Cu/Zn molar ratio is greater than 2.7 [32]. The increase in the amount of Zn2+ ions resulted in the structural transformation from rosasite to aurichalcite ([(Cu,Zn)5(CO3)2(OH)6])[31,32]. Aurichalcite contains four metal sites with different structures (marked as M1, M2, M3 and M4). Among them, M1 and M2 are coordinated with six O atoms to form an octahedral structure. M3 is coordinated with four O atoms to form a tetrahedral structure. M4 is situated on the five coordinated triangular bipyramid structure. Among these metal sites, M3 is completely occupied by Zn2+ ions, while Zn2+ and Cu2+ ions can simultaneously occupy the M1, M2, and M4 sites with the same probability. Cu-Zn composite oxide support with minerals as precursors were prepared by coprecipitation method and labeled as CuZn-x. Fig. 1 showed the XRD patterns of the precursors. Firstly, the diffraction range of 10–40° was a fingerprint region for the malachite, rosasite and aurichalcite. Peaks at 14.8°, 17.6°, 24.1°, 31.2°, 32.2° and 35.6° could be attributed to malachite. As could be found, in the absence of Zn, the precursor was in the malachite structure (CuZn-∞). When small amount of Zn ions was added, the structure of malachite did not change much. All the characteristic peaks of malachite were kept. However, the peaks at 31.2° and 32.2° shifted to 31.6° and 32.5°, respectively, which mainly because the cell shrinking when the Cu was replaced by the Zn. Moreover, the structure changed from malachite to rosasite. When larger amount of Zn was introduced (CuZn-7/3), the peaks at 31.2° and 32.2° shifted to 32.5° and 33.4° whose intensity decreased obviously. It meant the formation of rosasite structure which was not perfect. With further increase of the amount of Zn (CuZn-1), the peak at 31.2° shifted to 32.6° whose intensity further decreased. In addition, two new peaks at 13° and 34.3° assigned to aurichalcite appeared. The results showed that with the increase of the Zn content, the precursor transformed from malachite to rosasite and then to aurichalcite structure. 3.2 Characterization of Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts The CuO-ZnO mixed oxides supports were obtained from the calcination of the precursors. Table 1 showed the main physicochemical properties of the Au/CuxZn1−x catalyst and the actual loading of Au. The results revealed that the Au loading and the Cu/Zn molar ratio in the catalyst were basically consistent with the theoretical values. It was clear that the Au/CuO catalyst had the smallest specific surface area (14 m2/g), half of that for Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst. The pore volume of Au/CuO catalyst was also lower than of Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst. With the increase of Zn, the structure of the precursor changed, which led to the change of the microstructure of the catalysts. Fig. 2 illustrated the XRD patterns of the Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts. It could be seen that no diffraction peaks of the precursors were observed. The diffraction peaks at 35.6° and 38.7° could be attributed to CuO (002) and (111) faces. The Au/CuO catalyst exhibited intact and strong CuO characteristic peaks. While for Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts, the intensity of CuO peaks gradually decreased with the increase of Zn content, indicating that the addition of Zn effectively reduced the particle size of CuO and promote the dispersion of CuO. In addition, the diffraction peak of ZnO (100) at about 31.7° was detected for all Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts whose intensity of Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 was weakest. The new peak at around 36° could be attributed to ZnO (101). The above results indicated the high dispersion of ZnO species for Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst. With the increase of the amount of the Zn, the particle size of ZnO increased. On the other hand, no diffraction peak of Au was found, mainly due to the low loading of Au and the high dispersion of Au particle. Fig. 3 showed the H2-TPR profiles of the Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts, which could reflect the structural evolutions and the reduction properties of the catalysts. For all Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts, most of Au was in a metallic state as could be confirmed by the XPS. So, the peak mainly reflected the reduction of Cu species. It was found that the Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 sample showed the highest reduction temperature (255 °C), which might be related to the larger CuO particle size. Meanwhile, with the increase of the amount of Zn, the reduction temperature of the Au/CuxZn1−x catalyst gradually shifted to lower temperature. Among them, that of the Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst was the lowest (213 °C), which suggested the gradually decreased particle size of CuO. It was also consistent with the XRD results. In addition, the profile of Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst was different from that of Au/Cu0.7Zn0.3 and Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalysts i.e. the broad peak with a shoulder might be caused by the strong interaction between CuO and ZnO. The TEM images and the corresponding Au particle size distributions of the Au/CuxZr1−x catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 4. All CuO-ZnO supports showed the similar morphology. Upon increasing of the amount of Zn, the particle size of CuO gradually decreased, which was in accordance with the results of XRD. The small black dots in the TEM images were Au nanoparticles (NPs) which were uniformly dispersed on the support. Statistical analysis of 200 of Au nanoparticles displayed that the lower the addition of Zn, the smaller the average Au particle size. The Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst had the smallest Au particle size (2.24 nm). According to the results of H2-TPR, the interaction between CuO and ZnO was stronger, which promoted the dispersion of the Au particles. On the other hand, the Au particles of the Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 and Au/Cu0.7Zn0.3 catalysts had a relatively concentrated particle size distribution. While that of the Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst showed a relatively dispersed distribution. XPS spectra of Au 4 f over different Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts were compared in Fig. 5. All the spectra were referenced to the elemental carbon at binding energy (BE) of 284.1 eV. The binding energy of Au 4 f7/2 in the catalysts was about 84.1 eV. The spectra could be deconvoluted into two components, representing metallic Au0 and Auδ+, respectively. On the one hand, the surface content of Au0 decreased with the increase of the amount of Zn i.e. the most surface Au0 was observed over Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst. The strongest interaction between CuO and ZnO over Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst promoted the reduction and stability of Au species. On the other hand, as the amount of Zn increased, the binding energy of Au 4 f shifted toward lower values, indicating the strong interaction between Au and ZnO. Moreover, the properties of pure ZnO started to dominate. The formation of CuO-ZnO mixed oxide also affected the surface basicity of the catalyst. To explore the modification of the surface basicity, CO2-TPD was conducted ( Fig. 6). Considering the lower calcination temperature of the catalysts (200 °C), the CO2 desorption at temperatures below 200 °C were tested. Two main CO2 desorption peaks were observed in all samples, which all could be attributed to the weakly basic sites. With the increase of the amount of Zn, the intensity of the desorption peak gradually decreased, revealing the decreased number of basic sites on the catalyst surface. Quantitative information of surface basic sites could be obtained by peak fitting and calibration with MgCO3 as the reference. It was found that the amounts of basic sites over Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst was the largest, about 4.2 × 10−2 mmol/gcat. While that over Au/Cu0.7Zn0.3 catalyst is about 3.8 × 10−2 mmol/gcat. Meanwhile, that over the Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst was the smallest (3.4 ×10−2 mmol/gcat.). The addition of ZnO effectively adjusted the number of surface basic sites of the catalyst which mainly came from CuO species due to the low surface acidity of ZnO. The surface basic sites would facilitate the production of DHA. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between Zn/Cu molar ratios and the surface and structure properties of Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts. In the absence of Zn, the precursor structure was malachite. When small amount of Zn was added, the structure basically remained in the form of rosasite. With further increase of the amount of Zn, the rosasite structure gradually converted to aurichalcite, which could lead to varied properties of the catalysts. For Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts, the SBET of the catalysts increased for about 2 times with the increase of the amount of Zn. The number of surface basic sites decreased with the increase of the Zn/Cu molar ratio. The change in precursor structure also significantly affected the dispersion and chemical valence of Au. Upon increasing of the Zn amount, the dispersion of Au and the content of surface metallic Au all decreased. The highest content of surface metallic Au, the smallest Au particle size and the maximum amount of surface basic sites observed on Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 surface indicated that the catalytic activity was positively correlated with the Au dispersion, surface Au0 content and the number of surface basic sites. Meanwhile, the structure of the Au/CuO catalyst was slightly different from that of the Au/CuO-ZnO catalytic system. Despite the large Au particle size and smaller specific surface area, Au/CuO catalyst still showed good catalytic activity due to abundant basic sites and surface Au0. 3.3 Performance of Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts for glycerol oxidation to DHA Evaluations of selective oxidation of glycerol to DHA over Au/CuxZn1−x catalysts were performed at 50 °C and 0.2 MPa. The concentration of glycerol was 0.1 mol/L. The results were shown in Table 2. For comparison, the Au/CuO catalyst was also prepared by the same method. The evaluation results showed that the Au/CuO catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity than Au/Cu0.7Zn0.3 and Au/Cu0.5Zn0.5 catalyst while lower than that of Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1. The good catalytic performance of the Au/CuO catalyst was mainly attributed to the abundant basic sites and surface Au0. While for Au/CuxZn1−x, the conversion of glycerol decreased significantly with the increase of the addition of Zn. When the Cu/Zn molar ratio was 9, the Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst exhibited the highest glycerol conversion. Similar trend of the catalytic activity of Au/CuxZn1−x with the content of surface metallic Au, the dispersion of Au and the surface basic sites were observed. At same glycerol conversion, Au/CuO catalyst showed the highest DHA selectivity which decreased with the increase of the amount of Zn. Meanwhile, of acids selectivity increased with increasing of the amount of Zn, indicating that Zn modulated the selectivity of the products i.e. the presence of Zn promoted the oxidation of glycerol and the primary product, DHA. Thus, the selectivity of acids was positively correlated with the amount of Zn. Fig. 8 displayed the relationship between the catalytic performance of Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 and reaction conditions. From Fig. 8a, it was found that the conversion of glycerol gradually increased with the extension of the reaction time whose growth rate gradually slowed. When the reaction time was 8 h, the yield of DHA was the highest (70%). Further increase of the reaction time resulted in decreased yield of DHA due to further oxidation of DHA. Upon increasing of reaction temperature, the selectivity of DHA decreased gradually i.e. high temperature promoted the deep oxidation reaction, which increased the selectivity of C2 or other deep oxidation products (Fig. 8b). It was clearly found from Fig. 8c that the glycerol conversion increased with the increase of partial pressure of oxygen, which was consistent with the law of reaction kinetics. However, the DHA selectivity gradually decreased. Within the GLY/Au changed from 500 to 50, the conversion of glycerol increased and the selectivity of DHA changed greatly. When GLY/Au was lower than 50, with the further increase of the amount of Au, the selectivity of DHA changed little, suggesting that the surface Au of the catalyst was fully functional when the GLY/Au molar ratio was around 50. When the amount of Au was further increased, excess Au basically was not effective i.e. simply increasing the amount of catalyst was not enough to improve the catalytic performance. On the contrary, excess Au might promote the oxidation of DHA, which in turn reduced the selectivity of DHA. Comparing the above results, it was found that the reaction temperature had a great influence on the selectivity of DHA while the oxygen pressure had less effect on DHA selectivity. As could be observed in Fig. 8a, when the reaction time was 8 h, the glycerol conversion was about 80% with the selectivity of DHA of about 88%. When the temperature increased to 80 °C, the selectivity of DHA was about 65% at the same glycerol conversion (Fig. 8b). Reflected in Fig. 8c, the selectivity for DHA was approximately 88% at the same glycerol conversion, and the PO2 was 0.45 MPa. Meanwhile, at the same conversion, the DHA selectivity was about 87% (Fig. 8d), the GLY/Au molar ratio decreased to 30. In a word, at the same conversion of glycerol, increased reaction temperature, reaction time, oxygen pressure and Au/glycerol molar ratio could all reduce the selectivity of DHA, among which reaction temperature had the greatest effect. 3.4 Catalyst stability The stability of Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst was further investigated. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol-water mixture, dried and calcined at 200 °C for following recycles. Neither glycerol conversion nor DHA selectivity reduction was observed after five recycles ( Fig. 9), indicating that the catalyst exhibited good stability. To further explore the stability mechanism of the catalyst, a series of characterizations were conducted on both fresh and used catalysts. From the XRD patterns of fresh and used catalysts ( Fig. 10), it was clear that after the first recycle, the catalyst had the similar phase composition as the fresh catalyst. However, the half peak width of CuO diffraction peaks narrowed, indicating the increased CuO particles size. A new weak peak at 22° attributed to hexagonal carbolite phase appeared for the catalyst used after five recycles, suggesting a small amount of carbon deposition. On the other hand, with the increase of the recycles, the peak of ZnO was weakened, which revealed that ZnO gradually dispersed during the reaction. The above results suggested the slight changes in the catalyst structure after recycles (Fig. 10). Fig. 11 illustrated the TEM images and the size distribution of Au particles of fresh and used Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst. Obviously, with increasing of recycles, the size of CuO particles increased significantly, which was consistent with the results of XRD. It was very interesting that the size of Au particles increased significantly after the first recycle. However, as the recycles further increased, the Au particles size did not increase, indicating that CuO-ZnO composite oxide could effectively inhibit the growth of Au particles, thereby stabilizing the activity of the catalyst to a certain extent. On the other hand, despite the increase for the Au particle size after first recycle, the activity of the catalyst did not significantly decrease. Combined with the characterization results of XRD (Fig. 10), it could be speculated that, the redispersion of ZnO promoted the formation of active interface sites between Au and CuO, which suppressed the decrease in catalytic activity. From the XPS spectra of fresh and used Au/Cu0.9Zn0.1 catalyst ( Fig. 12), it was found that the binding energy of Au 4 f and the surface content of Au0 of the used Au/Cu0.9Zr0.1 catalyst changed a little, suggesting that no Au oxidation happened during the reaction. In summary, the better stability might because the stable support structure of rosasite that enhanced the interaction between the active component Au and the support, further stabilizing the particle size and the chemical valence of Au. 4 Conclusions Au catalysts supported on mineral-derived CuO-ZnO mixed oxides were used for glycerol oxidation to dihydroxyacetone in base-free condition. The activity evaluation showed that the catalyst with rosasite as the precursor showed the best catalytic activity (DHA yield of ∼70%). The characterization results revealed that as the molar ratio of Cu/Zn was changed, the structure of the precursor as well as the physiochemical and surface properties of the catalysts were changed which thus affected the Au dispersion and the chemical valence of Au. The best catalytic activity might because of the smallest Au particle size, largest content of Au0 and proper amount of basic sites. The good stability of the Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst might result from the strong interaction between CuO and ZnO from special mineral structure, which also enhanced the interaction between the support and Au, thus stabilizing the particle size and chemical valence of Au. The support using special mineral structure as precursor might be useful for improving the catalyst stability. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of glycerol to dihydroxyacetone (DHA) is a promising pathway for glycerol utilization. In order to fabricate a highly stable supported Au catalyst for the reaction, a series of CuO-ZnO mixed oxides derived from different minerals were synthesized. Then, the Au/CuO-ZnO catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation. High yield of DHA (70%) and conversion of glycerol (76%) were obtained over the rosasite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst. While over the aurichalcite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst, the yield of DHA was only 20%. By means of XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS, CO2-TPD characterization, it was found that the higher yield of DHA was attributed to the stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO, higher dispersion of Au species, higher content of Au0 and proper amount of surface basic sites. The rosasite-derived Au/CuO-ZnO catalyst also showed good stability and no obvious decrease in reactivity and DHA selectivity could be seen after five recycles. The stable structure of the support not only enhanced the interaction between CuO-ZnO that stabilized the support itself, but also improved the interaction between Au and the support, further stabilizing the particle size and chemical valence of Au.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidation of glycerol to dihydroxyacetone over highly stable Au catalysts supported on mineral-derived CuO-ZnO mixed oxide
